I like to have Pandas around in application that have an analytics / charting component. I'm well aware of how compiling numpy/pandas is a pain though. 

I think the main place where it is used is in the "Data Profiling" web views, that probably could ship as an Airflow plugins. I can't justify to the time to perform this surgery though... Installing numpy isn't that bad, and many will ask for the pandas library to use in their PythonOperator, so you may have to install it anyhow. Closing for now.

I'm hoping to iron out as many bugs as possible by then.

For the templated operators like `BashOperator` it's pretty easy to skip and succeed:

```
{% if params.is_dev %}
echo "success"
{% else %}
bash spark_command.sh
{% endif %}
```

We've been doing this for skipping tasks before a certain date for instance as in `{% if ds >= '2015-01-01' %}`

A more generic way could be (not a feature yet) to pass a `skip_and_succeed` param that expects a callable that receives the context object and skips and succeeds if the callable returns `True`. It may look something like this:

```
FooOperator(
    task_id='bar',
    skip_and_succeed=lambda context: return context['ds']<'2015-01-01',
    dag=dag,
)
```

It's easy for me to throw it in the context. Here's the PR:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/169
Passed the tests, mergin'

Cool. This works. 

```
# Operator : Read the parquet data and generate aggregate data
optional_aggregation_templated_command = """
    {% if params.ENV == "EP_PROD" %}
        echo "Skipping Aggregation in Prod Env"
    {% else %}
        ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa_spark root@10.10.2.157 '. /root/.bash_profile; /root/run_aggregation.sh {{ macros.ds_format(macros.ds_add(ds, -3), '%Y-%m-%d', '%s') }} {{ execution_date.strftime('%s') }}'
    {% endif %}
"""
aggregate_data_spark_job = BashOperator(
    task_id='aggregate_data_spark_job',
    execution_timeout=timedelta(hours=3),
    bash_command=optional_aggregation_templated_command,
    params={'ENV': ENV},
    dag=dag)
aggregate_data_spark_job.set_upstream(generate_new_parquet_files_spark_job)
```

It's a handy solution, but I guess I was thinking of the more general problem of handling branched flows that need to be joined later. Branching is a great feature, but with branching often comes joining. The legs of the branch could be different lengths. Currently, you set all descendants to "Skipped", but perhaps the code can be changed to set only those descendants to Skipped that do not join with a Non-skipped branch. In other words, we would need to set descendants to skipped until we come across a node that has multiple parents and one of those parents is not skipped.
BTW, I was not able to follow your FooOperator example. I'd like to keep this open in hopes there is a more generic join approach!

I tried to reproduce the behaviour on a separate setup on my local machine, but I couldn't. Still it occurred on our server.

I suspected malformed data in Redis. Thus we flushed all Celery data in Redis. After that I could not reproduce the behaviour on our server as well.

It seemed like that at the end temporarily async default_queue configurations among the workers might have caused the problem, which was the case for some time. Only bringing the config in sync didn't help, but flushing all the data in Redis did.

p.s. we are still running version 1.1.1, which at the end wasn't the cause of the problem. But we're anyways working right now on bringing our system to 1.2.0.

Best
I'm glad you could not reproduce as it's usually pretty hard to troubleshoot and even more so remotely. Reopen this task if it happens again, then we can try to get to the bottom of it.

It looks like it happens on the subquery that finds the latest task instances for the tasks in a DAG. I'm guessing it's a problem with the SqlAlchemy dialect, but won't dig in since we don't have any Postegres laying around.

This would shift Airflow DAGs from dependency graphs to dataflow graphs, which brings some interesting issues.  Output data would need to be serialized to the Airflow database to ensure execution could continue if workers need to be restarted.

You can turn off the examples in the config file seen here.

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/configuration.py#L14
Thanks.  What about other, non-example DAGs?  How do you turn those off, other than removing their files from the `dag_folder`?
I suppose if you set the start date of the dag to some date way in the future, you'll halt it until that time period.  Dag stays in tact, but doesn't run.
Thanks.

Also if you click on one of the looking glass one the left of the dag in the dag view, you will get to a menu.
I believe it can also be accessed through `https://localhost/admin/dagmodel/edit/?id=name_of_dag`. The to most checkbox is called is paused. If it is checked, then the dag will stop being scheduled.
Thanks.  Never knew that was there.
Restarting is a reasonable work-around. I'm closing this. Thanks.

There are so many ways, to recap:
- pause in the UI (magnifying glass in DAGs view / checkbox), there's a version of flask_admin with a bug where you have to click "Save and Continue" for the changes to take effect
- set an end_date in the past
- set retired tasks as `adhoc=True`
- remove from dags_folders
- i'm not 100% setting `start_date` in the future will work, I'd have to test or re-read the code...

https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/merging-vs-rebasing/workflow-walkthrough
You may have to hit the refresh button to force the DAG to refresh, it's the rightmost button on the screenshot and can be found on the DAGs page.

This button actually "expires" the DAG, forcing the different "DagBags" in the ecosystem to refresh from file. The scheduler has its own dagbag, as well as each web server thread, so refreshing it in one place doesn't solve the problem of freshness. The expiration is actually a timestamp in the database for that DAG that the DagBag looks up against periodically to see if it should reload the DAG.

There may be some bad behaviors to watch for around:
- files that get renamed/deleted
- conflicting dag_ids in multiple files

I think it was the stack trace below. This happens if you run 

```
$ airflow worker
```

on a freshly installed airflow with the defaults

```
broker_url = sqla+mysql://airflow:airflow@localhost:3306/airflow
celery_result_backend = db+mysql://airflow:airflow@localhost:3306/airflow
```

in the configuration file (with no mysql server running). The Exception does not raise if those values are properly set to a running rabbitmq instance.

Hi Folks!
I've changed the title of this issue to `Support a JoinPythonOperator to Work with the BranchPythonOperator Already Supported`. Prior to the creation of the BranchPythonOperator, we had ability to execute DAGs containing "diamond" topologies. With the advent and use of the BranchPythonOperator, we lost that ability, since every downstream node is labeled as `skipped`. I think the support of branching sets Airflow apart from other workflow engines, but it does require support for joining, as shown above. If this were available I would use it instead of the 'if-else' templating method, which I feel is less elegant.
@mistercrunch found an issue which I need to resolve before moving on this PR ... Always using mssql_default for some reason ... must of missed something when trying to utilize the new dbapi class.
@mistercrunch issue has been corrected ... should be good for review
Example of creating a connection:
We're honored to have you on board!

I need a few use cases to understand what everyone is trying to achieve with this feature. 

It seems fairly straightforward to publish a message for a task downstream and have that task downstream pick it up, and bring it up into its context (making it available in the operator's `execute` method as well as in the templates). 

It's also safe to assume that the message could be a "pickleabe" python object of limited size (probably smaller than 1MB). Right?

The question is how would the message be published? Is it an operator feature or a task feature? By that I mean is it baked into an operator, or is it baked when creating the task? 

Let's assume it's a task level feature. What if we had a parameter of `BaseOperator` called `drop_message` that expects a callable and calls it back after executing the task, passing it the context. Whatever is returned by that callable gets serialized and put into the database, and associated with that task instance. Downstream tasks can specify a `read_message`, most likely as a list of references to upstream tasks it's expecting messages from. These messages are made available in the context. Would that work for your use cases?
can you share the output of `pip freeze`?
Sounds right. We'd need the `skipped` state to propagate downstream until it hits a JoinOperator of some sort.

```
          pip freeze
```

Maybe a little clarification on this. The reason we extended this further was due to the fact, that adhoc queries to jdbc wouldn't work. In short, predefining jdbc connections wasn't possible, because there was no way to define jdbc driver location and jdbc driver classname. Now that's possible and everything works including adhoc queries.

At which interval is your scheduler running?
Look for `SCHEDULER_HEARTBEAT_SEC` in your airflow.cfg

Also, what's your `JOB_HEARTBEAT_SEC` set to?

As of now, `priority_weight` don't compute across DAGs. Many other features don't go across DAGs, upstream and downstream dependencies (clearing, backfilling, ...) don't go across DAGs either.

How big are your DAGs? It may be that you want all these tasks in a single DAG since they seem to be tightly coupled. We have many DAGs with hundreds of tasks and they behave well.

Another option is to crank up the priority_weight artificially.
As a side note, at Airbnb we tend to segment our DAGs based on large-ish subject areas, and we keep the full lineage from staging to warehouse in the same DAG.
Both are set to 5 seconds.

Thank you for reporting this!
Thanks a bunch!

About the UI customization, it's a nice flask-admin cutomization that optimizes for user experience but moves away from vanilla CRUD. I'm not sure if I want to optimize for user experience or ease of maintenance though. We could just document how to use the extras key/values very clearly and get rid of a bunch jdbc custom logic that requires knowledge of flask_admin/javascript/jinja to understand/evolve.

On the other hand it looks really nice and fits the JDBC use case.

What do you think?

Thanks, @mistercrunch.  My DAGs aren't particularly big.  None of them have more than 100 tasks.  I'll probably manually override the priority_weight for now, but look to consolidate the DAGs at some point.

I think it's a difficult decision. 

That said, if you want to get as many people/companies to use airflow as possible, it's probably worth doing a little UI customisation to get a bigger audience to use it. Usability will go a long way when it comes to that. Good documentation will mitigate this to a certain extend, but I think overall the changes that were necessary weren't that intrusive. Still, your argument is valid and it's a tradeoff worth discussing. Let's see if someone else has an opinion on the matter.

In the meantime I'll fix the other things.

My use case:

My steps:
1. Use BashOperator to list the data
2. Use HiveOperator to create tables and load data

So, I want to use BashOperator output to HiveOperator params

And there are no way for you to know ahead of time what the filenames are going to be? Are all the files targeting the same table?

Maybe you could write a FolderToHiveTransfer operator, or just a PythonOperator that does that. ?

Yep, the files are different tables. I do not how many, which table they have.
I will try use pythonoperator do that.

As long as the goal is to get data OUT OF mssql, then it's ok
![img](http://www.reactiongifs.com/r/rob.gif)

I think it's a somewhat legit use case, though it'd be nice to have a more defined "contract" with whoever drops those files. If you could have predictable filenames/folder and time interval it really simplifies ETL. Not only it simplifies the ETL logic, but the way the metadata and matching logs are organized.

But I understand that sometimes that's just the way it is and you have to deal with it...

Check what queue you're sending the task to. If u want the worker to process a certain queue run it with "-q queuename". If you send your tasks to the default queue it should work out of the box. No celery extra setup needed in any case.

relevant:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/161
@mistercrunch rebased with master to resolve merge conflicts

This triggered an interesting unrelated bug... Somehow since a previous refactor some operators depend on others (CheckOperators). Since order coming out of a dict is somewhat random, adding a new item in the dict in `operators/__init__.py` triggered things to come through in a different order where the dependency wasn't met. Anyhow, I pushed fix for this, I should be able to merge once the unit tests are all done.

We've been doing different things around Tableau integration but I don't think we've find something we're happy with. I wrote a little framework that would scan a Hive database ("tableau") and discover the all the tables from the metastore and push CSV files using the HiveToSamba operator. I think it would do differential loads where tables were partitionned.

I think we ended up settling on a pull approach using the Hortonworks hiveserver2 connector. 

We're interested in better integration between Tableau and Hive/Presto though. I haven't looked at the Tableau APIs lately.
